screeningSummary: Wildlife biologist with dermal ridge evidence - five-toed tracks from eight-foot bipedal creature

textVariants.text: You're on the air. I understand you have scientific credentials?
Alright, you're on. Scientific background, huh?
YOU ARE ON THE AIR! A scientist! This is gonna be GOOD!
You're on. Let me guess - you're gonna tell me you found Bigfoot?
You're on. So you work in science? What about it?
Oh, a SCIENTIST! This I gotta hear! What's your story?
You're on. What's your scientific background and field of expertise?

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Wildlife biologist, Vern. Thirty years in the field, PhD from Berkeley. What started as debunking turned into the most significant discovery of my career.

textVariants.text: You tried to debunk and ended up finding evidence instead?
Tried to debunk... ended up finding something. Alright, go on.
You TRIED TO DEBUNK and found EVIDENCE instead?! This is AMAZING!
Tried to debunk, huh? Let me guess - you found something you couldn't explain?
Tried to debunk. Fine, what'd you find?
TRIED TO DEBUNK and found something INCREDIBLE! I love this story already!
Initial debunking mission transformed into discovery. What specific evidence did you encounter?

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Olympic Peninsula, five years ago. I found track impressions that didn't match any known species. Bipedal, eighteen inches long, five toes with distinct dermal ridges.

textVariants.text: Dermal ridges. That's hard to fake. Tell me more.
Dermal ridges... alright, that's something. Go on.
DERMAL RIDGES?! That's INCREDIBLE! You can't fake that!
Dermal ridges. Okay, I'll admit - that's hard to fake.
Dermal ridges. That's... actually interesting. Keep going.
DERMAL RIDGES! This is PERFECT scientific evidence! Tell me everything!
Dermal ridges indicate biological origin. What was the depth distribution and stride length?

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Exactly. I photographed everything, made plaster casts, analyzed the weight distribution. Something heavy and biological made these. I've studied bear prints, cougar prints, human footprints. This was none of those.

textVariants.text: Could sophisticated hoaxers have created these? There are people who try to fake this evidence.
Look, could hoaxers have done this? People try, you know...
Could HOAXERS have created this?! The science doesn't lie though!
Right, because no one has ever faked evidence before. What makes this different?
Could be hoaxers. What's your take on that?
Could this be a HOAX? I mean, the science speaks for itself, right?!
Regarding potential hoaxing - what evidence suggests authentic biological origin versus manufactured prints?

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Dermal ridges require actual skin impression. You can't carve that in a mold. And the weight distribution was inconsistent - something a hoaxer wouldn't replicate. The stride length also suggests an animal eight to nine feet tall.

textVariants.text: Thank you for your work. We need more rigorous scientists in this field. Send us your documentation if you're willing.
Yeah, thanks for calling. Send stuff in if you want. We need more people like you.
This is INCREDIBLE! Send us EVERYTHING! Your documentation, your research - we need to share this!
Alright, that's... actually compelling. Send us your stuff if you want. Thanks.
Good work. Send your documentation in. We need more people doing real science.
This is PERFECT! Thank you for being a REAL scientist! Send us your work!
Thank you for applying rigorous methodology. Please submit your full documentation to our research team for peer review and analysis.

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: I've been quietly working with other researchers. The evidence is accumulating. The scientific community will have to face this eventually. Thanks for giving me a platform, Vern.

arcNotes: Wildlife biologist, dermal ridge evidence, published attempts blocked, collaboration with other researchers
